    Other QCfuns Functions in QC Workflow

    Create Demographic Rows

    qc_demo.Rd

    Function to create demographic rows

    Usage

    qc_demo(
  input,
  colvar = "TRT01P",
  stats_list = c("Mean_SD", "Median", "Range"),
  var_list,
  drop_var_list = NULL,
  max_digit = 2
)

    Arguments

    input

    input dataframe

    colvar

    column variable

    stats_list

    stats variables to display. Accepted values are c("Mean_SD", "Mean", "SD", "Median", "Range", "Min", "Max", "Geo_mean", "Geo_CV", "Geo_CL") and the order of variables matters

    var_list

    variable list in demo table. Please see details.

    drop_var_list

    Variable that don't keep all levels in the output

    max_digit

    maximum number of decimal place to report

    Value

    dataframe with demographic rows

    Details

    var_list should be a dataframe with desired variable names as column names, the label of each variable display in tables as the first row, and optionally, the number of decimal places to keep in the output as the second row. If the label row of a variable is empty, the row text and N row for this variable will be missing.

    Examples

    age <- sample(18:65, 10, replace = TRUE)

adsl <- data.frame(
  USUBJID = 1:10,
  TRT01P = factor(sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 10, replace = TRUE)),
  AGE = age,
  AGEGR1 = ifelse(age < 45, "< 45", ">= 45"),
  SEX = factor(sample(c("Female", "Male"), 10, replace = TRUE)))
  
### Create variable list based on DPS and assign labels to them.
### Leave "" For variables that concatenate to the corresponding categorical variables
var_list <- data.frame(
  AGE = "Age, years",
  AGEGR1 = "",
  SEX = "Sex"
  )

tab1 <- qc_demo(adsl, colvar = "TRT01P", var_list = var_list)
tab1
#>      row_text            A           B            C
#> 1  Age, years         <NA>        <NA>         <NA>
#> 2           N            5           2            3
#> 3   Mean (SD) 41.6 (18.88) 57.5 (0.71) 44.0 (15.39)
#> 4      Median         44.0        57.5         48.0
#> 5       Range     (18; 65)    (57; 58)     (27; 57)
#> 6        < 45    3 (60.0%)        <NA>    1 (33.3%)
#> 7       >= 45    2 (40.0%)  2 (100.0%)    2 (66.7%)
#> 8         Sex         <NA>        <NA>         <NA>
#> 9           N            5           2            3
#> 10     Female    3 (60.0%)   1 (50.0%)    2 (66.7%)
#> 11       Male    2 (40.0%)   1 (50.0%)    1 (33.3%)
